duchenne.title: Hope for Children with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)
duchenne.subtitle: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a rare genetic condition that causes progressive muscle weakness and degeneration, primarily in boys. While there is currently no cure, advances in gene therapy, medications, and physical rehabilitation offer new hope for improving quality of life. Through medical tourism, families gain access to leading international hospitals and cutting-edge treatments that may not be available in their home country. On this page, you will find essential information about DMD, the latest therapeutic options, and how we support families seeking world-class medical care abroad.

about.title: What is Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)?
paragraphs: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the DMD gene, which is responsible for producing dystrophin â€” a protein essential for muscle cell integrity.
Without dystrophin, muscle cells gradually deteriorate, leading to progressive loss of strength and mobility. DMD primarily affects boys, with symptoms typically appearing between ages 2 and 5.
Early signs include delayed walking milestones, frequent falls, difficulty climbing stairs, and calf muscle enlargement due to fat accumulation (pseudohypertrophy).

rows.description: Mutations in the DMD gene leading to absence of dystrophin
Gradual loss of muscle function; wheelchair use typically by age 12

items.name: Elevidys (delandistrogene moxeparvovec)
items.description: Approved by the FDA in 2023 for children aged 4â€“5 with confirmed DMD gene mutations. In 2024, approval was extended to ambulatory and non-ambulatory patients aged 4 and older. Elevidys delivers a shortened version of dystrophin (micro-dystrophin) to muscle cells. However, in 2025, dosage limitations were introduced for non-ambulatory patients due to cases of acute liver failure, requiring careful evaluation with specialists (Roche, 2025).

items.name: Del-zota (delpacibart zotadirsen)
items.description: An experimental treatment by Avidity Biosciences for patients with exon 44-skippable mutations. In the EXPLORE44 phase 1/2 trial, Del-zota increased dystrophin production up to 25% of normal and reduced creatine kinase levels to near-normal. FDA approval submission expected by end of 2025 (Avidity Biosciences, 2025).

items.name: Corticosteroids
items.description: Medications like prednisone and deflazacort help slow muscle degeneration and delay wheelchair dependence.

items.name: Experimental Drugs
items.description: Research focuses on reducing inflammation and fibrosis, and enhancing muscle regeneration (Frontiers, 2021).

items.name: Duvyzat (givinostat)
items.description: The first non-steroidal treatment approved by the FDA in 2024 for patients aged 6 and up. Suitable for all genetic DMD types (FDA, 2024).

items.name: Stretching and Exercise
items.description: Helps prevent contractures and maintain mobility.

items.name: Assistive Devices
items.description: Braces and wheelchairs enhance mobility and independence.

items.name: Multidisciplinary Care
items.description: Involves neurologists, physiotherapists, and cardiologists to provide comprehensive treatment (Mayo Clinic, 2025).
Therapies aimed at regenerating muscle tissue.
Medications to support heart and diaphragm function.
Cellular and protein therapies for improving muscular performance (Muscular Dystrophy Association, 2023).

rows.description: Introduction of a functional dystrophin gene
rows.limitations: Limited availability, risk of side effects

rows.advantages: Improves mobility and quality of life

impact.title: How DMD Affects Quality of Life for Children and Families
impact.intro: DMD profoundly impacts both patients and their loved ones:
paragraphs: Physical challenges: Muscle weakness restricts children's ability to participate in everyday activities. By adolescence, most require a wheelchair, reducing independence (Cleveland Clinic, 2025).
Emotional and social impact: Studies show children with DMD often face social isolation and emotional distress, affecting self-esteem and mental well-being (ScienceDirect, 2016).
Family burden: Caring for a child with DMD demands emotional, physical, and financial resources, including healthcare costs and time commitment (ResearchGate, 2011).
